1895-09-15 00:00:00 Scene 6 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

This experience planted the seed of her future as a merchant, showing her the potential for independence and self-sufficiency.

She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.

        AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?

          Answer

        • Della Plumstone can make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the fruit.

        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:00:00.

They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the fruit.

      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is trying to buy fruit from Lennon Figtree in the Fruitville market square and is negotiating a price with him.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make an offer to Lennon Figtree for the fruit.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make an offer to Lennon Figtree.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?

      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

1895-09-15 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
      Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is currently selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is negotiating with Della Plumstone over the price of a basket of apples. The current date and time is September 15, 1895, shortly after midnight.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is currently selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is negotiating with Della Plumstone over the price of a basket of apples. The current date and time is September 15, 1895, shortly after midnight.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced the bustling marketplace for the first time. The vibrant colors and intoxicating scents overwhelmed them, but their father's hand in theirs provided a sense of security as they navigated the crowds. Lennon was captivated by the energy and the sense of community, vowing to one day have their own stall amidst the lively exchange.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother prepare baskets of ripe peaches for the market. As they carefully arranged the fruit, their mother taught them about the importance of selecting the best produce and treating each piece with care. Lennon learned that even the smallest act of attention could make a difference in the quality of their offerings.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their parents to let them take a small cart to the neighboring town to sell their family's surplus fruit. The journey was long and tiring, but Lennon's infectious enthusiasm and genuine smile charmed every customer they encountered. They returned home with an empty cart and a heart full of pride, their first taste of independence and entrepreneurial spirit.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they met a seasoned merchant who shared invaluable wisdom about the art of negotiation and the importance of building relationships with customers. Lennon listened intently, absorbing the advice like a sponge, recognizing that success was not just about selling fruit, but about connecting with people and creating a sense of community.

        Question_1
      • Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer
          State
        • Option 1 is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins. Option 2 is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:00:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?


          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins. Option 2 is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.
          Time
        • 1895-09-15 00:00:00
        ObservationSummary
      • Summary of recent observations
          Key
        • Summary of recent observations
          Value
        • [14 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples.
          Chain of thought


        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          ['[15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.', '[15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples.
        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.6.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins. Option 2 is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.6.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins. Option 2 is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7 and 0.3. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.6.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 1.3. For Option 2, UCB is 1.6.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.6.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
        Question_3
      • Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.

        • For Option 1, UCB is 1.3. For Option 2, UCB is 1.6.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose.           [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?


          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is selling fruit at the market in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins. Option 2 is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and try to negotiate a higher price.
          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7 and 0.3. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4 and 0.6.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Scene 7 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.

          Della Plumstone's The current date/time is:
          15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is negotiating the purchase of apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. Della wants to pay 4 coins, while Lennon is asking for at least 5.
          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is negotiating the purchase of apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. Della wants to pay 4 coins, while Lennon is asking for at least 5.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she accompanied her father on a trading trip to a neighboring town. She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is trying to buy apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. They are haggling over the price, with Della offering 4 coins and Lennon wanting at least 5.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can make another offer to Lennon Figtree.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to make another offer to Lennon Figtree.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 5 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (e)

    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

Always use third-person limited perspective.

        • [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell a basket of apples to Della Plumstone at the market. Della has offered 2 coins, but Lennon thinks the apples are worth more. The current date and time is September 15, 1895, between 12:10 AM and 12:15 AM.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is trying to sell a basket of apples to Della Plumstone at the market. Della has offered 2 coins, but Lennon thinks the apples are worth more. The current date and time is September 15, 1895, between 12:10 AM and 12:15 AM.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother prepare baskets of ripe peaches for the market. As they carefully arranged the fruit, their mother taught them about the importance of selecting the best produce and treating each piece with care. Lennon learned that even the smallest act of attention could make a difference in the quality of their offerings.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their parents to let them take a small cart to the neighboring town to sell their family's surplus fruit. The journey was long and tiring, but Lennon's infectious enthusiasm and genuine smile charmed every customer they encountered. They returned home with an empty cart and a heart full of pride, their first taste of independence and entrepreneurial spirit.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they met a seasoned merchant who shared invaluable wisdom about the art of negotiation and the importance of building relationships with customers. Lennon listened intently, absorbing the advice like a sponge, recognizing that success was not just about selling fruit, but about connecting with people and creating a sense of community.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

        Question_1
      • Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer
          State
        • Option 1 is to accept Della's offer of 2 coins.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are both unknown, so the answer is 0.5.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Della's offer of 2 coins.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are both unknown, so the answer is 0.5.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples. Della has offered 2 coins, but Lennon believes they are worth more.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Della's offer of 2 coins.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.2 and 0.8.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 1.8.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are both unknown, so the answer is 0.5.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) accept
          (b) reject
          Answer: (a)
        Question_3
      • Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.

        • For Option 1, UCB is 1.8.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Question: Compute {agent_name}'s personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.2 and 0.8.
          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 1.8.

        • 1895-09-15 00:10:00

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for a basket of apples. Della has offered 2 coins, but Lennon believes they are worth more.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Scene 8 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Della. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Della. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
      Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Della. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
