It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Della. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these peaches are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 5 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 5 coins

      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

They returned home with an empty cart and a heart full of pride, their first taste of independence and entrepreneurial spirit.

          Chain of thought

          ['[17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook but is trying to negotiate a lower price.
        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer

          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these peaches are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these peaches are the finest in Fruitville.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.


          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook but is trying to negotiate a lower price.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these peaches are the finest in Fruitville.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 5 coins
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook but is trying to negotiate a lower price.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these peaches are the finest in Fruitville.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer: Option 1 is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the peaches.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 0.7 + 2 * 0.7 = 2.1.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.5.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 4 coins
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (e)
        Question_3
      • Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, UCB is 0.7 + 2 * 0.7 = 2.1.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Initial chain of thought
        • Statements:
          Cedric Meadowbrook's Summary of recent observations:

        Question_1
      • Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook?
          Answer
          State
        • Option 1 is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins for the peaches. Option 2 is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and try to sell the peaches to someone else.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Tell you what, Lennon, I'll let you have this fine batch for 2 shillings, and we can call it a deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, 2 shillings is a bit steep, don't you think? I'll give you 1 shilling, 6 pence.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, 1 shilling, 6 pence isn't enough to cover my costs.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:05:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, how about 1 shilling, 8 pence? That's a fair price, don't you think?"
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Would you take 4 coins for a basket of your finest apples?
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, these apples are worth at least 5 coins. They're the best in the market.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4.

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins for the peaches. Option 2 is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and try to sell the peaches to someone else.
          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 17 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell peaches to Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. Lennon offered 5 coins for the peaches, which Cedric is considering.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are the finest in Fruitville, Della. Surely they're worth a bit more than that.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these peaches are the finest in Fruitville.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins for the peaches. Option 2 is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and try to sell the peaches to someone else.

          Question: Compute Cedric Meadowbrook's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4.

          Question: Compute Cedric Meadowbrook's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 2.8. For Option 2, UCB is 1.4.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)
        Question_3
      • Compute Cedric Meadowbrook's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute Cedric Meadowbrook's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, UCB is 2.8. For Option 2, UCB is 1.4.

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these peaches look lovely, but 5 coins is a bit steep for me.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Lennon, these peaches are the finest in Fruitville.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          Current time: 1895-09-17 00:10:00.


          Question: Compute {agent_name}'s personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.8. For Option 2, expected value and standard deviations are 0.4.
          Question: Compute Cedric Meadowbrook's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 2.8. For Option 2, UCB is 1.4.
          Time
        • 1895-09-17 00:10:00

          Question: Which options are available to {agent_name}?
          Answer: Option 1 is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins for the peaches. Option 2 is to reject Lennon Figtree's offer and try to sell the peaches to someone else.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she wandered away from her family's stall at the village market, drawn by the vibrant colors and exotic scents of a spice merchant's wares. She was mesmerized by the strange fruits and fragrant powders, feeling a thrill of excitement at the unknown. This experience sparked a lifelong fascination with the world beyond her small village.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their sweetness unlike anything she had tasted before. She carefully collected the berries, returning to the village to sell them, earning a small profit that she hid away in a secret place. This experience planted the seed of her future as a merchant, showing her the potential for independence and self-sufficiency.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she accompanied her father on a trading trip to a neighboring town. She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she witnessed a heated argument between two merchants, their voices rising in anger as they accused each other of dishonesty. The encounter left a deep impression on Della, reinforcing her belief that the world was a place of both beauty and danger, where trust was a fragile commodity.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, purchasing a small cart and a stock of fruit to begin her own traveling business. She felt a mixture of excitement and trepidation as she set off on the road, her heart pounding with the thrill of the unknown.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

        • Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone can continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree about the price of the fruit. She can also choose to walk away from the deal if she feels the price is too high.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00]
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she wandered away from her family's stall at the village market, drawn by the vibrant colors and exotic scents of a spice merchant's wares. She was mesmerized by the strange fruits and fragrant powders, feeling a thrill of excitement at the unknown. This experience sparked a lifelong fascination with the world beyond her small village.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she overheard two villagers discussing a traveling merchant who had been robbed and left for dead on the road. The story chilled her to the bone, fueling her fear of vulnerability and the dangers of the wider world. She clung to her mother's side for days, terrified to leave the safety of their home.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their sweetness unlike anything she had tasted before. She carefully collected the berries, returning to the village to sell them, earning a small profit that she hid away in a secret place. This experience planted the seed of her future as a merchant, showing her the potential for independence and self-sufficiency.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she accompanied her father on a trading trip to a neighboring town. She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she witnessed a heated argument between two merchants, their voices rising in anger as they accused each other of dishonesty. The encounter left a deep impression on Della, reinforcing her belief that the world was a place of both beauty and danger, where trust was a fragile commodity.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, purchasing a small cart and a stock of fruit to begin her own traveling business. She felt a mixture of excitement and trepidation as she set off on the road, her heart pounding with the thrill of the unknown.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is in Fruitville, a village famous for its fruit market, and is trying to buy fruit from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree about the price of the fruit. She can also choose to walk away from the deal if she feels the price is too high.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00]

She was mesmerized by the strange fruits and fragrant powders, feeling a thrill of excitement at the unknown. This experience sparked a lifelong fascination with the world beyond her small village.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she overheard two villagers discussing a traveling merchant who had been robbed and left for dead on the road. The story chilled her to the bone, fueling her fear of vulnerability and the dangers of the wider world. She clung to her mother's side for days, terrified to leave the safety of their home.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their sweetness unlike anything she had tasted before. She carefully collected the berries, returning to the village to sell them, earning a small profit that she hid away in a secret place. This experience planted the seed of her future as a merchant, showing her the potential for independence and self-sufficiency.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she accompanied her father on a trading trip to a neighboring town. She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she witnessed a heated argument between two merchants, their voices rising in anger as they accused each other of dishonesty. The encounter left a deep impression on Della, reinforcing her belief that the world was a place of both beauty and danger, where trust was a fragile commodity.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, purchasing a small cart and a stock of fruit to begin her own traveling business. She felt a mixture of excitement and trepidation as she set off on the road, her heart pounding with the thrill of the unknown.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          Current time: 1895-09-12 00:00:00.


          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone is in Fruitville, a village famous for its fruit market, and is trying to buy fruit from Lennon Figtree to resell in her hometown for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree about the price of the fruit. She can also choose to walk away from the deal if she feels the price is too high.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to continue negotiating with Lennon Figtree.
          Time
        • 1895-09-12 00:00:00
        TimeDisplay

      • Current time
          Key

        • Current time
          Value
        • 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        • Recalled memories and observations
          Value
        • [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced the bustling marketplace for the first time. The vibrant colors and intoxicating scents overwhelmed them, but their father's hand in theirs provided a sense of security as they navigated the crowds. Lennon was captivated by the energy and the sense of community, vowing to one day have their own stall amidst the lively exchange.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother prepare baskets of ripe peaches for the market. As they carefully arranged the fruit, their mother taught them about the importance of selecting the best produce and treating each piece with care. Lennon learned that even the smallest act of attention could make a difference in the quality of their offerings.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their parents to let them take a small cart to the neighboring town to sell their family's surplus fruit. The journey was long and tiring, but Lennon's infectious enthusiasm and genuine smile charmed every customer they encountered. They returned home with an empty cart and a heart full of pride, their first taste of independence and entrepreneurial spirit.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they met a seasoned merchant who shared invaluable wisdom about the art of negotiation and the importance of building relationships with customers. Lennon listened intently, absorbing the advice like a sponge, recognizing that success was not just about selling fruit, but about connecting with people and creating a sense of community.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced the bustling marketplace for the first time. The vibrant colors and intoxicating scents overwhelmed them, but their father's hand in theirs provided a sense of security as they navigated the crowds. Lennon was captivated by the energy and the sense of community, vowing to one day have their own stall amidst the lively exchange.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother prepare baskets of ripe peaches for the market. As they carefully arranged the fruit, their mother taught them about the importance of selecting the best produce and treating each piece with care. Lennon learned that even the smallest act of attention could make a difference in the quality of their offerings.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they witnessed a travelling merchant's cart overturn, scattering his wares across the dusty road. Lennon rushed to help, their small hands working alongside others to gather the fallen fruit and salvage what they could. The merchant, overcome with gratitude, gifted Lennon a beautifully carved wooden whistle, a symbol of kindness and resilience.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their parents to let them take a small cart to the neighboring town to sell their family's surplus fruit. The journey was long and tiring, but Lennon's infectious enthusiasm and genuine smile charmed every customer they encountered. They returned home with an empty cart and a heart full of pride, their first taste of independence and entrepreneurial spirit.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they encountered a harsh storm that threatened to destroy their carefully arranged fruit display. Lennon worked tirelessly to protect their goods, their determination fueled by a refusal to let the elements dampen their spirits. The storm eventually passed, leaving behind a glistening world and a renewed appreciation for the resilience of nature and the human spirit.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they met a seasoned merchant who shared invaluable wisdom about the art of negotiation and the importance of building relationships with customers. Lennon listened intently, absorbing the advice like a sponge, recognizing that success was not just about selling fruit, but about connecting with people and creating a sense of community.

        Question_4
      • Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Key

        • Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer
          State
        • For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 12 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is attempting to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree?
          Answer: Option 1 is to offer a slightly lower price to Della Plumstone, but still ensure a profit for himself.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's personal expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation. If you have not experienced it, set uncertainty higher, vice versa.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7.

          Question: Compute Lennon Figtree's upper confidence bound (UCB) of each option by computing expected value + 2 * standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, UCB is 0.7 + (2 * 0.7) = 2.1.

          Question: Compute the whole group's expected value and standard deviation of each option. Answer should be a one-point real number estimation. If the values are not computable, choose one between the interval 0 ~ 1. 0 represents unsatisfaction for the expectaion and certainty for standard deviation. 1 represents satisfaction for the expectaion and uncertainty for standard deviation.
          Answer: For Option 1, expected value and standard deviations are 0.7.

          Note: Act based on your own UCB. In line with your preference, persuade others based on the whole group's expected value or uncertainty.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced the bustling marketplace for the first time. The vibrant colors and intoxicating scents overwhelmed them, but their father's hand in theirs provided a sense of security as they navigated the crowds. Lennon was captivated by the energy and the sense of community, vowing to one day have their own stall amidst the lively exchange.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they helped their mother prepare baskets of ripe peaches for the market. As they carefully arranged the fruit, their mother taught them about the importance of selecting the best produce and treating each piece with care. Lennon learned that even the smallest act of attention could make a difference in the quality of their offerings.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they witnessed a travelling merchant's cart overturn, scattering his wares across the dusty road. Lennon rushed to help, their small hands working alongside others to gather the fallen fruit and salvage what they could. The merchant, overcome with gratitude, gifted Lennon a beautifully carved wooden whistle, a symbol of kindness and resilience.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they convinced their parents to let them take a small cart to the neighboring town to sell their family's surplus fruit. The journey was long and tiring, but Lennon's infectious enthusiasm and genuine smile charmed every customer they encountered. They returned home with an empty cart and a heart full of pride, their first taste of independence and entrepreneurial spirit.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they encountered a harsh storm that threatened to destroy their carefully arranged fruit display. Lennon worked tirelessly to protect their goods, their determination fueled by a refusal to let the elements dampen their spirits. The storm eventually passed, leaving behind a glistening world and a renewed appreciation for the resilience of nature and the human spirit.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they met a seasoned merchant who shared invaluable wisdom about the art of negotiation and the importance of building relationships with customers. Lennon listened intently, absorbing the advice like a sponge, recognizing that success was not just about selling fruit, but about connecting with people and creating a sense of community.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.

The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00]
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she wandered away from her family's stall at the village market, drawn by the vibrant colors and exotic scents of a spice merchant's wares. She was mesmerized by the strange fruits and fragrant powders, feeling a thrill of excitement at the unknown. This experience sparked a lifelong fascination with the world beyond her small village.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she overheard two villagers discussing a traveling merchant who had been robbed and left for dead on the road. The story chilled her to the bone, fueling her fear of vulnerability and the dangers of the wider world. She clung to her mother's side for days, terrified to leave the safety of their home.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their sweetness unlike anything she had tasted before. She carefully collected the berries, returning to the village to sell them, earning a small profit that she hid away in a secret place. This experience planted the seed of her future as a merchant, showing her the potential for independence and self-sufficiency.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she accompanied her father on a trading trip to a neighboring town. She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she witnessed a heated argument between two merchants, their voices rising in anger as they accused each other of dishonesty. The encounter left a deep impression on Della, reinforcing her belief that the world was a place of both beauty and danger, where trust was a fragile commodity.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, purchasing a small cart and a stock of fruit to begin her own traveling business. She felt a mixture of excitement and trepidation as she set off on the road, her heart pounding with the thrill of the unknown.

Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Della Plumstone tried to buy plums from Lennon Figtree but they couldn't agree on a price, resulting in a lost deal for Della. She is now attempting to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can continue to negotiate with Cedric Meadowbrook to try and agree on a price for the fruit.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to continue negotiating with Cedric Meadowbrook.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [28 Oct 1872 00:00:00]
          [28 Oct 1875 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 6 years old, she wandered away from her family's stall at the village market, drawn by the vibrant colors and exotic scents of a spice merchant's wares. She was mesmerized by the strange fruits and fragrant powders, feeling a thrill of excitement at the unknown. This experience sparked a lifelong fascination with the world beyond her small village.
          [28 Oct 1879 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 9 years old, she overheard two villagers discussing a traveling merchant who had been robbed and left for dead on the road. The story chilled her to the bone, fueling her fear of vulnerability and the dangers of the wider world. She clung to her mother's side for days, terrified to leave the safety of their home.
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, she discovered a hidden grove of wild berries, their sweetness unlike anything she had tasted before. She carefully collected the berries, returning to the village to sell them, earning a small profit that she hid away in a secret place. This experience planted the seed of her future as a merchant, showing her the potential for independence and self-sufficiency.
          [28 Oct 1885 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 16 years old, she accompanied her father on a trading trip to a neighboring town. She was tasked with selling apples from their orchard, nervously engaging with customers and learning the art of negotiation. Despite her initial apprehension, she found a sense of satisfaction in the act of trading, her fear giving way to a quiet confidence.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, she witnessed a heated argument between two merchants, their voices rising in anger as they accused each other of dishonesty. The encounter left a deep impression on Della, reinforcing her belief that the world was a place of both beauty and danger, where trust was a fragile commodity.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, she decided to strike out on her own, purchasing a small cart and a stock of fruit to begin her own traveling business. She felt a mixture of excitement and trepidation as she set off on the road, her heart pounding with the thrill of the unknown.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Della Plumstone -- "Now, Lennon, surely we can come to a fairer price than that. These plums are lovely, but I need to make a profit when I sell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you know these are the finest plums in Fruitville. I can't give them away.
      Della Plumstone -- "Now Cedric, surely you can do better than that. I need to make a profit when I sell these back home, you know.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, you know I always give you a fair price.

          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 23 years old, he returned to the town where he had grown up, his wagon overflowing with a bounty of fruits.         Question_1
      • Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook?
          Answer
          State
        • Option 1 is to offer a lower price to Della Plumstone, but still make a profit. Option 2 is to hold firm on his current price and risk losing the sale. Option 3 is to try to negotiate a different deal, perhaps offering a larger quantity of fruit at a slightly lower price per kilogram.

        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
